description:
Buchananella felis is a species of bacteria that is commonly found in the gastrointestinal tract of domestic cats (Felis catus). It is a Gram-negative, obligate anaerobic bacterium, meaning it can only survive and grow in the absence of oxygen.

Buchananella felis is a member of the Bacteroidaceae family and is considered a commensal organism, meaning it typically lives in harmony with its host without causing any known harm. It is believed to play a role in the maintenance of a healthy gut microbiome in cats, contributing to the overall balance and function of the feline digestive system.

The exact physiological and ecological functions of Buchananella felis within the cat's gut are still being studied, but it is likely involved in the breakdown and fermentation of complex carbohydrates and the production of short-chain fatty acids, which can provide energy for the host and support intestinal health.

This bacterial species has been the subject of limited research, and its potential interactions with other gut microbiota, as well as its potential role in feline health and disease, are areas that warrant further investigation.
prompt: Provide a short scientific description of this species: Buchananella felis
